clinical_study.brief_title: Emergency Department Fascia Iliaca Blocks and Pre-operative Opioid Requirements in Hip Fracture Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Emergency Department Fascia Iliaca Blocks and Pre-operative Opioid Requirements in Hip Fracture Patients: a Prospective Cohort Study

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if non-continuous local anesthetic fascia iliaca blocks performed in the emergency department are effective for preoperative analgesia in hip fracture patients. Investigators hypothesize that patients with these blocks will have lower opioid requirements than patients in a historical group in whom blocks were not performed.

primary_outcome.measure: Total Pre-op IV Morphine Equivalents (TIVME) per 24 hour period
primary_outcome.time_frame: From Date of admission until date of surgery, approximately 48 hours
primary_outcome.description: IV morphine equivalent dosing per 24 hour period

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From Date of admission until date of surgery, approximately 48 hours

arm_group.description: Prospective patients receiving fascia iliaca blocks A prospective Observational study of Hip fracture patients that are offered fascia iliaca blocks as standard of care in the ED.

No fascia iliaca block performed A retrospective review will be done of hip fracture patients that did not receive fascia iliaca blocks (before fascia iliaca blocks being offered in the ED as standard of care).

study_pop.textblock: All patients >65 years of age presenting to Spectrum Health Butterworth hospital with low-energy hip fractures (displaced and non-displaced femoral neck, pertrochanteric-type including subtrochanteric extension) will be screened for the study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- low energy femoral neck and pertrochanteric-type hip fractures
- age 65+
Exclusion Criteria:
- pathologic fractures (tumor)
- high energy fractures
- concomitant fractures besides hip fractures
- chronic home opioid exposure prior to hospitalization
- moderate to severe dementia
- pre-fracture hospitalization
- standard contraindications to fascia iliaca blocks (local anesthetic allergy, cellulitis over injection site, etc.)
